WILL GO DOWN IN TRADITION
Senior Class Week to Set Record in Hopkins Annals Committees Announce
Final Dates and Arrangements
for All the Affairs.

\\ ith the definite announcement of dates and with the completion of the work of the various
committees, the Hopkins stage is
in readiness for one of the most
varied, the most unusual, and the
most eventful Senior Weeks the
University has ever witnessed.
The curtain will rise on Thursday, June 8, two days after the
last Hopkins examination ever to
be held in McCoy Hall. On that
day will come two affairs, a the
dansant in the afternoon and the
Senior Prom at night. The the
dansant will be given to the Class
of 1916 by Dean Brush. This announcement was made at the
senior class meeting on May 24,
and comes as another manifestation of the close personal interest
always taken by the Dean in the
affairs of the class—an interest, it
may be added, which the seniors
deeply appreciate.
The the dansant will take place
at Homewood, the Senior Prom in
McCoy Hall. There will be eight
hours of dancing that day, three
in the afternoon and five at night,
and even then, a member of the
senior class has been heard to remark nonchalantly that 1916 has
never found itself constrained by
limits.
On Friday will come the boat
ride, open to all students of the
University. The boat will leave
early in the morning, and will return at about eleven in the evening.
The senior "party" will take
place on Saturday at Thompson's,
near River View. The arrangements for this affair are hidden in
a dark cloud of mystery. \Tickers,
c kiirman of the "party" committee, will divulge nothing and only
smilingly promises that the affair
wilt be worthy of Hopkins tradition.
On Monday, June 12, comes
Class Day. At two o'clock a minstrel show will be given which has
been arranged by the Class Day
committee, consisting of Fricke,
chairman, Hale and Primrose, and
which promises to be one of the
cleverest features of the entire
week. Next "Hs" will be awarded for spring sports and for debating, and then will come addresses by President Goodnow,
Dean Brush, Dr. Latane, honorary president of .the class, and T.
J. Tingley, president.
Graduation will take place at
the Academy of Music on Tuesday afternoon, and at night the
faculty will hold a reception for
the class.
At the recent meeting, President Tingley appointed a committee consisting of Bagley, chairman, McDowell, Fricke, Hayes
and Primrose to provide for future class reunions.

THE JOHNS' HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 29, 1916. •
DR. NEARING'S REMOVAL UNJUST
Committee of American Association of
University Professors, Headed by Professor Lovejoy, Censures Action
of Pennsylvania Trustees.

That the removal of Prof. Scott
Nearing from the Wharton School
of the University of Pennsylvania
was a direct infringement of academic freedom is the opinion of
the committee of inquiry appointed by the American Association of
University Professors. The committee was headed by Arthur 0.
Lovejoy, of this University.
The committee makes its report
in the latest Association Bulletin.
It summarizes its findings as follows:
I. As to the procedure followed
by the board of trustees in its action with reference to this member of the university faculty, the
following facts are established:
1. The position held by Dr.
Nearing was one carrying a definite presumption of reappointment, in case of satisfactory service.
2. It was duly made known to
the board of trustees by the department of economics and by the
dean of the Wharton School that
Dr. Nearing's service was regarded as satisfactory; and he was expressly, recommended for reappointment. The Board was also
informed by the dean that this
recoommendation had the sub-

stantial support of the Wharton
School faculty.
3. This recommendation of the
qualified representatives of the
educational staff of the Wharton
School was rejected by the board
of trustees on June 14 without
further conailtation with those
representatives, without reference
of the case for judicial inquiry to
any faculty committee, and (originally) without assignment of reason.
4. The board's own action on
June 14 was not judicial in character. No opportunity for a hearing upon the charges or criticisms
made against him was afforded
Dr. Nearing; nor did the board
conduct any inquiry on its own
account to ascertain whether the
persons outside the university,
by whose criticisms the board declares its action to have been determined, had been correctly informed as to Dr. Nearing's utterances or had correctly understood
them, or whether their criticisms
were, in fact, justified by the authentic language of the utterances
in question.
The committee holds that such
procedure provides no proper
safeguard for academic freedom;
that it gives the individual academic teacher no adequate security against substantial injustice;
and that it secures to the faculty
or its representatives no sufficient
voice in relation to questions of
reappointment and removal.

II. As to the grounds or causes
of the action of the board of trustees in refusing Dr. Nearing reappointment, the two following
facts are established, and appear
to the committee decisive.
1. The only statement of reasons which the board as a whole
has officially given, declares this
action to have been made necessary by the attitude taken towards
Dr. Nearing by persons outside
the board, including some who
knew him only by his public utterances.
2. The most important representatives of such an attitude of
disapproval and antagonism towards Dr. Nearing were a group
of alumni of conservative views,
whose criticisms had been repeatedly voiced in the Alumni Register and in the reports of the alumni committee on the Wharton
School. The objections of these,
as of certain other known critics
of Dr. Nearing, were expressly
based, at least in part, upon the
character of his economic opinions
and the content of his utterances
upon social questions.
The committee is accordingly
compelled to conclude that at
least a contributory cause of Dr.
Nearing's removal was the opposition of certain persons outside
the university to the views, upon
questions within his own field of
study, expressed by him in his
extra-mural addresses. Removal
or refusal of appointment, wholly
or partly upon such a ground,
without judicial inquiry by any
committee of fellow-economists or
other scholars, the committee can
only regard as an infringement of
academic freedom.
The report concludes with expressions of approval of the action
of the board of trustees of the
University of Pennsylvania on
December 20, 1915, when the regulations previously in force with
regard to the tenure of teaching;
positions were considerably modified.
In addition to Prof. Lovejoy,
the committee was composed of
Prof. Davis R. Dewey, of the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Prof. Henry W. Farnam,
of Yale University; Prof. Franklin
H. Giddings, of Columbia University, and Prof. Roscoe Pound, of
Harvard University.

SPEAKER FOR COMMENCEMENT
NOT YET ANNOUNCED

The commencement ceremonies
will be held on Tuesday afternoon, June 13th, at the Academy
of Music. Dr. John H. Strong, of
the Eutaw Place Baptist Church,
will give the opening prayer.
yet the speaker to give the main
address has not been announced.
Dr. Goodnow, the president of the
University, will be the presiding
officer and will confer the diplomas upon the graduates of the different departments of the University. The music will be given by
Fisher's Orchestra.
In the evening a reception to the
graduates will be given in McCoy
Hall. This will be one of the largest affairs of the college year; the
number of graduates and their
friends is expected to reach seven
or eight hundred. Fisher's Orchestra will play, and later in the
evening there will be dancing.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 29, 1916.
The Proposed Freshman Regulations.

The recommendations of the
committee of Juniors appointed to
consider advisable changes in the
Freshman regulations should be
adopted in full. They come at a
time which offers unequalled opportunity for growth of University spirit; they will satisfy a demand which otherwise may vent
itself in more public manifestations of the type of the one seen
this year; and they have behind
them the weight of student opinion, expressed directly through
the Student Council.
In themselves, the regulations
are no more drastic than those in
existence at nearly every widelyknown college or University.
"Granted that Freshmen should be
subject to certain obligations before they can be admitted to a full
share in University life—and so
much is tacitly granted by all student and faculty institutions—the
proposed increase in those obligations is only one which the coming change of location makes entirely natural. The only reason
Hopkins Freshmen have never
worn the skull caps which other
universities require is because
Hopkins has been situated in the
heart of'a large city; neither this

nor any other of the proposed regulations is too severe to be put
into execution—the ducking procedure suggested is an entirely innocuous ritual strongly recommended by its undeniable poetic
significance.
Nothing has a worse effect upon
both the reputation and the actual
welfare of a University than unlicensed hazing; yet, unless adequate provision be made, after the
removal to Homewood, such hazing may well crop out. What is
required is a definite agreement
between the Faculty and the three
upper classes to the effect that,
with the imposition of authorized
regulations upon the Freshmen,
no hazing of any sort will be countenanced. The regulations now
under consideration meet with the
whole-hearted endorsement of the
students; they should be adopted
with the understanding that any
violation of either their letter or
their spirit by upper classmen, as
well as by Freshmen, will be
promptly punished by the Student
Council itself.
Contrast.

There will be a strong element
of the dramatic in the coming two
weeks. First come examinations,
final examinations, with tragedy
on printed slips and Nemesis in
the scratch of a pen, with work,
work, and always work, and then
—Senior Week.
The contrast involved is more
than a contrast between shirtsleeves and dancing pumps; it is
a contrast between the two elements which, combined, represent
the life of any American college
or university. In the strictest
sense, neither an examination nor
a boat ride may be called entirely
cultural, yet in the discovery of
-.-,1_7at each means and of the balance which must be effected between the two, lies a good part of
a university education. For, to
the senior, final examinations represent the climax of the intellectual work of four years, and Senior
Week incorporates the traditions
of forty years and the spirit of a
class.
The Hopkins senior is neither a
grind nor a professional dancer.
Fe does not live exclusively on
books or on champagne, nor is his
guiding star either the midnight
lamp or the Ziegtield footlight. He
is pre-eminently a man who has
begun to learn how to appreciate
his life. He realizes that there
can be no better zest than that of
labor well performed, and that a
life of only labor can be attacked
on grounds both social and ethical.
In these last intense weeks he
is epitomized.
Concentration,
drama, keen thinking and keen
living, the best a university has to
offer, is summed up for him in the
space of a fortnight.

I

A Word as to Football.
By Coach Henry Brennick

It seems a far cry from the present time to the opening of the
football season of 1916, but if the
lessons of preparedness which we
now read and hear about have had
any effect whatever, we must
realize that now is the time for us
to make ready for our coming
football campaign, and by making
ready, I mean that all prospective
players should have their academic standing at such a grade
that they cannot be declared ineligible for the team next fall. It
behooves every man, therefore,
for the few days that remain before final examinations, to work,
and to work hard, so that when
the fall comes he will not be bemoaning the fact that the fates are
against him and that the dean is
quite unjust in his particular case.
Next fall Hopkins will need
every available man, and for any
man to be lost to the squad because of academic failure should
be considered a disgrace in the
eyes of the whole student body.
We shall start the season with
many losses and with many advantages. Our greatest loss is, of
course, in not having Charlie
Brickley back with us, for every
one knows how valuable an adjunct he was to Hopkins football
and how much good his splendid
spirit accomplished among the
members of the squad. Our other
great loss is the loss of Wilkinson,
the giant tackle, and the sturdy
Liebensperger, together with the
other men who will not be here to
play next year. This latter loss.
however, is somewhat offset by
the fact that Wilkinson is to act
as coach, and, as one person
know has remarked, if he proves
as good a coach as he was a player, then Hopkins will not lose
much by the change of his position.
Hopkins gains by the wholly
changed mental attitude of the
University toward football am
compared with what it was at the
opening of the 1915 season. In
the fall of 1915 the University had
behind it a very disastrous season, whereas now it has the confidence gained from many games
well played and extremely worthy
opponents defeated. In Captain
Brooks the University squad has
a leader who possesses all the attributes that that word implies,
and besides this he has the example of Primrose, who showed

in his last two games'last season,
what is demanded of and what is
to be performed by a Hopkins
captain.
The schedule next year is bound
to prove an extremely difficult
one, so that for this reason alone
we must have a large and efficient
squad. Modern football no longer
permits a football team to be con
stituted of only eleven men; experience has shown that the team
with the more competent substitutes is invariably returned the
winner. Indeed, a prominent football strategist recently remarked
that a football team these days
should contain at least thirty well
trained and well qualified members. With the team alone numbering thirty, the squad should
contain at least seventy.
Training will begin on Thursday, September 14th, in order that
the conditioning of the men may
be well advanced by the time the
first game comes along. I urge all
players, therefore, to see to it that
your vacations be so arranged that
you will be able to report on that
day. See to it, also, that you lead
a good, clean, normal life during
the summer, so that you will report for practice in good shape.
To conclude, study hard now,
that you may be eligible for the
team and be prepared to report for
morning and afternoon practice
on September 14th. Do these
things and the coaching staff will
in its turn unite with you in giving the University the caliber of
team it of right expects.
Stud:nts at Vanderbilt University recently adopted an amendment for the iniative and referendum and recall of their class representatives, and another amendment which provided for a poll
tax of 15 cents.
An "open house" night has recently been established at Hillsdale by members of the faculty. By
this method the students are expected to become better acquainted
with the faculty.
An interesting feature of the
summer session at Darthmouth this
year will be a course in drama and
pageantry. A series of lectures will
be given by such men as Clayton
Hamilton, Percy Mackaye and Leo
Wilson Dood.
-In a recent competition between
Harvard, Columbia, Darthmouth,
Penn State, Pennsylvania and
Princeton, the Glee Club of the
last organization won the intercollegiate trophy.

FACULTY MAKES SUMMER PLANS

THE JOHNS IIOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY
SOPHOMORE TENNIS TEAM
DEFEATS FRESHMEN

Some to Spend Vacation in Travel and
Rest, Others Will Teach at Summer
Schools or Arrange Departments at Homewood.

‘Vith the college term almost
over, Hopkins professors are all
busy making their summer plans.
Some expect to spend a few weeks
of rest and seclusion at their summer homes, while others expect to
teach in summer schools.
The Dean is planning to motor
to Rome, N. Y., and stop on the
way at West Point, in order that
he may see the cadets drill there,
and so be able to raise the standard
of the training at Homewood.
Prof. Bright, the head of the
English Department, will remain
in Baltimore until his library has
been moved to Homewood. After
that he will not follow his usual
custom of going to England, but
will spend his vacation in New England. Dr. French will seek rest
at his summer home in Blue Ridge
Summit; and Dr. Janney will spend
the summer in study at his home
in Purcellville, Va., and in Washington. Professor Green will be
at his summer home in Massachusetts.
Dr. Roulston is to conduct the
Intercollegiate Examinations at
Ilomewood, and will afterwards
teach in the Hopkins Summer
School. Dr. Worthington, of the
French Department, according to
his custom, will give instruction
at the University of Virginia.
Professor Vincent will spend the
summer in the Georgian Bay region, in Canada.
In the Classical Department,
Prof. Kirby Flower Smith will
leave for Rome on the 17th, crossing on the Philadelphia to Liverpool; thence through England and
France to Italy. There he will continue his work on an old Italian
poem, the Membriano of Circo da
Terrara, which he began there last
year and which can be completed
only there. Prof. Spicker has not
yet made definite plans for the
summer, but will probably take a
trip West.
Prof. Robinson is planning to
spend his vacation at Gloucester,
Mass., working part of the time
in the Boston Museum and the
Harvard Library. During the last
week of June, Dr. Magoffin is to
he the supervisor of the College
Entrance Board examinations at
Tome. The following week will
be occupied in moving and arranging the Archaeological collections
in the Academic Building at Homewood, after which he will teach
Greek and Roman History at Columbia, and then will spend the
rest of the summer at Southwest
Harbor, Mt. Desert Island. Me.
Prof. Bliss's vacation will be
ent at York Harbor.
Prof. Ames is not planning an
extensive vacation, but will take
short trips now and then, when his
work in the Hopkins Summer
School permits. Of those profes-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1916.
Edits Translation of Grotius.

Dr. Ralph V. D. Magoffin has
Just published his latest work,
"Grotius • on the Freedom of the
Seas." It is gotten out by the Oxford University Press under the
auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and
is a translation from Latin of an
old book, "Marc Liberum," written in 1608 by Grotius. The conditions at the present moment are
practically the same as those written about in "Marc Liberum," and
if the names of the old places were
given their modern terms, the
book would seem to be an up-todate treatise on international law.
Cotillon Board Elects Officers.

At the last meeting of the Cotillon Board officers were elected
for the year 1916-1917. Robert
Merrick, '17, was chosen chairman; William Skinner, '17, treasurer, and Franklin Cromwell, '18,
secretary. The new board will
make no definite plans as to the
dates of the dances until the opening of the University next fall, but
has already announced that all
three cotillons will be held at
Homewood.
1913 Class of B. C. C. to Have Reunion.

A movement for a re-union banquet of the 1913 Class of the Baltimore City College has been started
by several Juniors who are City
College graduates. Lawrence Baker, former president of the B. C.
C. '13 class, has appointed a reunion committee, consisting of
William A. McKewan, Alexander
A. Steinbach, and Albert P. Brower. A large number of the members of the Junior Class came from
the City College, and are expected
to attend the banquet.
Twenty-six law students at
Texas made an average of 95 per
cent, during the past term according to the statistics just given out
by the regisrar of the Law Department. One hundred and fifty-five
,• students, nearly half of the number enrolled, maintained a general
, average of 90.per cent, or more.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1916.

FOOTBALL MEN HOLD MEETING

TEN DEPARTMENTS REPRESENTED

Coaches Brennick and Wilkinson, Captain Brooks and Manager Davis Talk
to Players—Fall Practice to
Begin September 14.

Hopkins Summer School Will Have 30
Courses for Undergraduates and 52
for Graduates--Credit of Eight
Points Can Be Obtained.

At an enthusiastic meeting of
the football men last Monday in
the Trophy Room, plans were
gone over for the coming season,
and a schedule of work was outlined for the men during the summer months. Speeches were made
by Head Coach "Hank" Brennick,
Assistant Coach Paul Wilkinson,
Captain Brooks and Manager
Davis.
Coach Brennick announced that
practice would begin this year on
September 14th, as with the first
game scheduled for October 9th,
an early start was imperative. He
also laid stress on training during
vacation time, and asked especially that men intending to attend
military camps would do so early
in the summer. Due to the strenuous work in the camps, he said,
he was of the opinion that the men
would not be particularly inclined
to hard practice immediately after
military maneuvers. He also emphasized the fact that hard and serious practice were requisites for
a successful team, and asked that
the men help him turn out one of
the best teams that ever represented the Black and Blue.
Wilkinson, former captain and
all-state tackle, who will have
charge of the linemen this year,
also laid stress on the necessity
for hard work and earnest co-operation with the coaches. Captain
Brooks then spoke on the prospects and asked all to help in turning out another championship
eleven. Manager Davis outlined
the schedule for next season, and
the meeting disbanded with rousing cheers for coaches and captain.
Among the men present at the
meeting, several of whom are vet.erans, were: Finney, Ormond,
Primrose, Schmidt, Frank, Sonneborn, Woodward, Uhler, Martindale, Bowers, Brooks, Cox, Hoffman, Darley, Brumbaugh, Stanley
and Benson.

Ten departments of the University are represented in the list
of courses that may be offered by
advanced Ftudents at the Johns
Hopkins Summer School. The
program of twenty-four courses
includes the departments of chemistry, economics, education, English, German, history, mathematics, physics, politics and
psychology. In a number of instances the instruction to be given
will be along lines that are in addition to the work available during the regular session, such as
the money market and the European war, experimental education,
secc.ndary school teaching, • two
epochs of reform in German lahgnage and style, Pan-American
relations, radioactivity, international law and the European war,
and the experimental study of the
affective processes.
Undergraduate students in the
Academic Department will find an
array of thirty courses from which
their selections may be made.
These are in the departments of
biology, chemistry, economics,
education, English composition
and literature, French, geography,
German, history, Latin, mathematics, physics, politics, psychology and Spanish.
The former two-course rule regulating the choice of summer
courses has been modified. Students may elect two or three
courses for credit, at their own
option. The amount of credit that
may be earned is specified in accordance with the number so
elected. The maximum number,
of points that can be earned in
one session is eight points.
Undergraduate students in the
Department of Engineering can
offer for credit cow ses in chemistry, English composition and literature, French, German, mathematics and physics. A , new arrangement in the history of Englishb literature will make it possible to accomplish a full year's
course in two summer sessions.

WILL GO DOWN IN TRADITION
Senior Class Week to Set Record in Hopkins Annals Committees Announce
Final Dates and Arrangements
for All the Affairs.

\\ ith the definite announcement of dates and with the completion of the work of the various
committees, the Hopkins stage is
in readiness for one of the most
varied, the most unusual, and the
most eventful Senior Weeks the
University has ever witnessed.
The curtain will rise on Thursday, June 8, two days after the
last Hopkins examination ever to
be held in McCoy Hall. On that
day will come two affairs, a the
dansant in the afternoon and the
Senior Prom at night. The the
dansant will be given to the Class
of 1916 by Dean Brush. This announcement was made at the
senior class meeting on May 24,
and comes as another manifestation of the close personal interest
always taken by the Dean in the
affairs of the class—an interest, it
may be added, which the seniors
deeply appreciate.
The the dansant will take place
at Homewood, the Senior Prom in
McCoy Hall. There will be eight
hours of dancing that day, three
in the afternoon and five at night,
and even then, a member of the
senior class has been heard to remark nonchalantly that 1916 has
never found itself constrained by
limits.
On Friday will come the boat
ride, open to all students of the
University. The boat will leave
early in the morning, and will return at about eleven in the evening.
The senior "party" will take
place on Saturday at Thompson's,
near River View. The arrangements for this affair are hidden in
a dark cloud of mystery. \Tickers,
c kiirman of the "party" committee, will divulge nothing and only
smilingly promises that the affair
wilt be worthy of Hopkins tradition.
On Monday, June 12, comes
Class Day. At two o'clock a minstrel show will be given which has
been arranged by the Class Day
committee, consisting of Fricke,
chairman, Hale and Primrose, and
which promises to be one of the
cleverest features of the entire
week. Next "Hs" will be awarded for spring sports and for debating, and then will come addresses by President Goodnow,
Dean Brush, Dr. Latane, honorary president of .the class, and T.
J. Tingley, president.
Graduation will take place at
the Academy of Music on Tuesday afternoon, and at night the
faculty will hold a reception for
the class.
At the recent meeting, President Tingley appointed a committee consisting of Bagley, chairman, McDowell, Fricke, Hayes
and Primrose to provide for future class reunions.

THE JOHNS' HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 29, 1916. •
DR. NEARING'S REMOVAL UNJUST
Committee of American Association of
University Professors, Headed by Professor Lovejoy, Censures Action
of Pennsylvania Trustees.

That the removal of Prof. Scott
Nearing from the Wharton School
of the University of Pennsylvania
was a direct infringement of academic freedom is the opinion of
the committee of inquiry appointed by the American Association of
University Professors. The committee was headed by Arthur 0.
Lovejoy, of this University.
The committee makes its report
in the latest Association Bulletin.
It summarizes its findings as follows:
I. As to the procedure followed
by the board of trustees in its action with reference to this member of the university faculty, the
following facts are established:
1. The position held by Dr.
Nearing was one carrying a definite presumption of reappointment, in case of satisfactory service.
2. It was duly made known to
the board of trustees by the department of economics and by the
dean of the Wharton School that
Dr. Nearing's service was regarded as satisfactory; and he was expressly, recommended for reappointment. The Board was also
informed by the dean that this
recoommendation had the sub-

stantial support of the Wharton
School faculty.
3. This recommendation of the
qualified representatives of the
educational staff of the Wharton
School was rejected by the board
of trustees on June 14 without
further conailtation with those
representatives, without reference
of the case for judicial inquiry to
any faculty committee, and (originally) without assignment of reason.
4. The board's own action on
June 14 was not judicial in character. No opportunity for a hearing upon the charges or criticisms
made against him was afforded
Dr. Nearing; nor did the board
conduct any inquiry on its own
account to ascertain whether the
persons outside the university,
by whose criticisms the board declares its action to have been determined, had been correctly informed as to Dr. Nearing's utterances or had correctly understood
them, or whether their criticisms
were, in fact, justified by the authentic language of the utterances
in question.
The committee holds that such
procedure provides no proper
safeguard for academic freedom;
that it gives the individual academic teacher no adequate security against substantial injustice;
and that it secures to the faculty
or its representatives no sufficient
voice in relation to questions of
reappointment and removal.

II. As to the grounds or causes
of the action of the board of trustees in refusing Dr. Nearing reappointment, the two following
facts are established, and appear
to the committee decisive.
1. The only statement of reasons which the board as a whole
has officially given, declares this
action to have been made necessary by the attitude taken towards
Dr. Nearing by persons outside
the board, including some who
knew him only by his public utterances.
2. The most important representatives of such an attitude of
disapproval and antagonism towards Dr. Nearing were a group
of alumni of conservative views,
whose criticisms had been repeatedly voiced in the Alumni Register and in the reports of the alumni committee on the Wharton
School. The objections of these,
as of certain other known critics
of Dr. Nearing, were expressly
based, at least in part, upon the
character of his economic opinions
and the content of his utterances
upon social questions.
The committee is accordingly
compelled to conclude that at
least a contributory cause of Dr.
Nearing's removal was the opposition of certain persons outside
the university to the views, upon
questions within his own field of
study, expressed by him in his
extra-mural addresses. Removal
or refusal of appointment, wholly
or partly upon such a ground,
without judicial inquiry by any
committee of fellow-economists or
other scholars, the committee can
only regard as an infringement of
academic freedom.
The report concludes with expressions of approval of the action
of the board of trustees of the
University of Pennsylvania on
December 20, 1915, when the regulations previously in force with
regard to the tenure of teaching;
positions were considerably modified.
In addition to Prof. Lovejoy,
the committee was composed of
Prof. Davis R. Dewey, of the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Prof. Henry W. Farnam,
of Yale University; Prof. Franklin
H. Giddings, of Columbia University, and Prof. Roscoe Pound, of
Harvard University.

SPEAKER FOR COMMENCEMENT
NOT YET ANNOUNCED

The commencement ceremonies
will be held on Tuesday afternoon, June 13th, at the Academy
of Music. Dr. John H. Strong, of
the Eutaw Place Baptist Church,
will give the opening prayer.
yet the speaker to give the main
address has not been announced.
Dr. Goodnow, the president of the
University, will be the presiding
officer and will confer the diplomas upon the graduates of the different departments of the University. The music will be given by
Fisher's Orchestra.
In the evening a reception to the
graduates will be given in McCoy
Hall. This will be one of the largest affairs of the college year; the
number of graduates and their
friends is expected to reach seven
or eight hundred. Fisher's Orchestra will play, and later in the
evening there will be dancing.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 29, 1916.
The Proposed Freshman Regulations.

The recommendations of the
committee of Juniors appointed to
consider advisable changes in the
Freshman regulations should be
adopted in full. They come at a
time which offers unequalled opportunity for growth of University spirit; they will satisfy a demand which otherwise may vent
itself in more public manifestations of the type of the one seen
this year; and they have behind
them the weight of student opinion, expressed directly through
the Student Council.
In themselves, the regulations
are no more drastic than those in
existence at nearly every widelyknown college or University.
"Granted that Freshmen should be
subject to certain obligations before they can be admitted to a full
share in University life—and so
much is tacitly granted by all student and faculty institutions—the
proposed increase in those obligations is only one which the coming change of location makes entirely natural. The only reason
Hopkins Freshmen have never
worn the skull caps which other
universities require is because
Hopkins has been situated in the
heart of'a large city; neither this

nor any other of the proposed regulations is too severe to be put
into execution—the ducking procedure suggested is an entirely innocuous ritual strongly recommended by its undeniable poetic
significance.
Nothing has a worse effect upon
both the reputation and the actual
welfare of a University than unlicensed hazing; yet, unless adequate provision be made, after the
removal to Homewood, such hazing may well crop out. What is
required is a definite agreement
between the Faculty and the three
upper classes to the effect that,
with the imposition of authorized
regulations upon the Freshmen,
no hazing of any sort will be countenanced. The regulations now
under consideration meet with the
whole-hearted endorsement of the
students; they should be adopted
with the understanding that any
violation of either their letter or
their spirit by upper classmen, as
well as by Freshmen, will be
promptly punished by the Student
Council itself.
Contrast.

There will be a strong element
of the dramatic in the coming two
weeks. First come examinations,
final examinations, with tragedy
on printed slips and Nemesis in
the scratch of a pen, with work,
work, and always work, and then
—Senior Week.
The contrast involved is more
than a contrast between shirtsleeves and dancing pumps; it is
a contrast between the two elements which, combined, represent
the life of any American college
or university. In the strictest
sense, neither an examination nor
a boat ride may be called entirely
cultural, yet in the discovery of
-.-,1_7at each means and of the balance which must be effected between the two, lies a good part of
a university education. For, to
the senior, final examinations represent the climax of the intellectual work of four years, and Senior
Week incorporates the traditions
of forty years and the spirit of a
class.
The Hopkins senior is neither a
grind nor a professional dancer.
Fe does not live exclusively on
books or on champagne, nor is his
guiding star either the midnight
lamp or the Ziegtield footlight. He
is pre-eminently a man who has
begun to learn how to appreciate
his life. He realizes that there
can be no better zest than that of
labor well performed, and that a
life of only labor can be attacked
on grounds both social and ethical.
In these last intense weeks he
is epitomized.
Concentration,
drama, keen thinking and keen
living, the best a university has to
offer, is summed up for him in the
space of a fortnight.

A Word as to Football.
By Coach Henry Brennick

It seems a far cry from the present time to the opening of the
football season of 1916, but if the
lessons of preparedness which we
now read and hear about have had
any effect whatever, we must
realize that now is the time for us
to make ready for our coming
football campaign, and by making
ready, I mean that all prospective
players should have their academic standing at such a grade
that they cannot be declared ineligible for the team next fall. It
behooves every man, therefore,
for the few days that remain before final examinations, to work,
and to work hard, so that when
the fall comes he will not be bemoaning the fact that the fates are
against him and that the dean is
quite unjust in his particular case.
Next fall Hopkins will need
every available man, and for any
man to be lost to the squad because of academic failure should
be considered a disgrace in the
eyes of the whole student body.
We shall start the season with
many losses and with many advantages. Our greatest loss is, of
course, in not having Charlie
Brickley back with us, for every
one knows how valuable an adjunct he was to Hopkins football
and how much good his splendid
spirit accomplished among the
members of the squad. Our other
great loss is the loss of Wilkinson,
the giant tackle, and the sturdy
Liebensperger, together with the
other men who will not be here to
play next year. This latter loss.
however, is somewhat offset by
the fact that Wilkinson is to act
as coach, and, as one person
know has remarked, if he proves
as good a coach as he was a player, then Hopkins will not lose
much by the change of his position.
Hopkins gains by the wholly
changed mental attitude of the
University toward football am
compared with what it was at the
opening of the 1915 season. In
the fall of 1915 the University had
behind it a very disastrous season, whereas now it has the confidence gained from many games
well played and extremely worthy
opponents defeated. In Captain
Brooks the University squad has
a leader who possesses all the attributes that that word implies,
and besides this he has the example of Primrose, who showed

in his last two games'last season,
what is demanded of and what is
to be performed by a Hopkins
captain.
The schedule next year is bound
to prove an extremely difficult
one, so that for this reason alone
we must have a large and efficient
squad. Modern football no longer
permits a football team to be con
stituted of only eleven men; experience has shown that the team
with the more competent substitutes is invariably returned the
winner. Indeed, a prominent football strategist recently remarked
that a football team these days
should contain at least thirty well
trained and well qualified members. With the team alone numbering thirty, the squad should
contain at least seventy.
Training will begin on Thursday, September 14th, in order that
the conditioning of the men may
be well advanced by the time the
first game comes along. I urge all
players, therefore, to see to it that
your vacations be so arranged that
you will be able to report on that
day. See to it, also, that you lead
a good, clean, normal life during
the summer, so that you will report for practice in good shape.
To conclude, study hard now,
that you may be eligible for the
team and be prepared to report for
morning and afternoon practice
on September 14th. Do these
things and the coaching staff will
in its turn unite with you in giving the University the caliber of
team it of right expects.
Stud:nts at Vanderbilt University recently adopted an amendment for the iniative and referendum and recall of their class representatives, and another amendment which provided for a poll
tax of 15 cents.
An "open house" night has recently been established at Hillsdale by members of the faculty. By
this method the students are expected to become better acquainted
with the faculty.
An interesting feature of the
summer session at Darthmouth this
year will be a course in drama and
pageantry. A series of lectures will
be given by such men as Clayton
Hamilton, Percy Mackaye and Leo
Wilson Dood.
-In a recent competition between
Harvard, Columbia, Darthmouth,
Penn State, Pennsylvania and
Princeton, the Glee Club of the
last organization won the intercollegiate trophy.

FACULTY MAKES SUMMER PLANS

THE JOHNS IIOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY
SOPHOMORE TENNIS TEAM
DEFEATS FRESHMEN

Some to Spend Vacation in Travel and
Rest, Others Will Teach at Summer
Schools or Arrange Departments at Homewood.

‘Vith the college term almost
over, Hopkins professors are all
busy making their summer plans.
Some expect to spend a few weeks
of rest and seclusion at their summer homes, while others expect to
teach in summer schools.
The Dean is planning to motor
to Rome, N. Y., and stop on the
way at West Point, in order that
he may see the cadets drill there,
and so be able to raise the standard
of the training at Homewood.
Prof. Bright, the head of the
English Department, will remain
in Baltimore until his library has
been moved to Homewood. After
that he will not follow his usual
custom of going to England, but
will spend his vacation in New England. Dr. French will seek rest
at his summer home in Blue Ridge
Summit; and Dr. Janney will spend
the summer in study at his home
in Purcellville, Va., and in Washington. Professor Green will be
at his summer home in Massachusetts.
Dr. Roulston is to conduct the
Intercollegiate Examinations at
Ilomewood, and will afterwards
teach in the Hopkins Summer
School. Dr. Worthington, of the
French Department, according to
his custom, will give instruction
at the University of Virginia.
Professor Vincent will spend the
summer in the Georgian Bay region, in Canada.
In the Classical Department,
Prof. Kirby Flower Smith will
leave for Rome on the 17th, crossing on the Philadelphia to Liverpool; thence through England and
France to Italy. There he will continue his work on an old Italian
poem, the Membriano of Circo da
Terrara, which he began there last
year and which can be completed
only there. Prof. Spicker has not
yet made definite plans for the
summer, but will probably take a
trip West.
Prof. Robinson is planning to
spend his vacation at Gloucester,
Mass., working part of the time
in the Boston Museum and the
Harvard Library. During the last
week of June, Dr. Magoffin is to
he the supervisor of the College
Entrance Board examinations at
Tome. The following week will
be occupied in moving and arranging the Archaeological collections
in the Academic Building at Homewood, after which he will teach
Greek and Roman History at Columbia, and then will spend the
rest of the summer at Southwest
Harbor, Mt. Desert Island. Me.
Prof. Bliss's vacation will be
ent at York Harbor.
Prof. Ames is not planning an
extensive vacation, but will take
short trips now and then, when his
work in the Hopkins Summer
School permits. Of those profes-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1916.
Edits Translation of Grotius.

Dr. Ralph V. D. Magoffin has
Just published his latest work,
"Grotius • on the Freedom of the
Seas." It is gotten out by the Oxford University Press under the
auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and
is a translation from Latin of an
old book, "Marc Liberum," written in 1608 by Grotius. The conditions at the present moment are
practically the same as those written about in "Marc Liberum," and
if the names of the old places were
given their modern terms, the
book would seem to be an up-todate treatise on international law.
Cotillon Board Elects Officers.

At the last meeting of the Cotillon Board officers were elected
for the year 1916-1917. Robert
Merrick, '17, was chosen chairman; William Skinner, '17, treasurer, and Franklin Cromwell, '18,
secretary. The new board will
make no definite plans as to the
dates of the dances until the opening of the University next fall, but
has already announced that all
three cotillons will be held at
Homewood.
1913 Class of B. C. C. to Have Reunion.

A movement for a re-union banquet of the 1913 Class of the Baltimore City College has been started
by several Juniors who are City
College graduates. Lawrence Baker, former president of the B. C.
C. '13 class, has appointed a reunion committee, consisting of
William A. McKewan, Alexander
A. Steinbach, and Albert P. Brower. A large number of the members of the Junior Class came from
the City College, and are expected
to attend the banquet.
Twenty-six law students at
Texas made an average of 95 per
cent, during the past term according to the statistics just given out
by the regisrar of the Law Department. One hundred and fifty-five
,• students, nearly half of the number enrolled, maintained a general
, average of 90.per cent, or more.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 29, 1916.

FOOTBALL MEN HOLD MEETING

TEN DEPARTMENTS REPRESENTED

Coaches Brennick and Wilkinson, Captain Brooks and Manager Davis Talk
to Players—Fall Practice to
Begin September 14.

Hopkins Summer School Will Have 30
Courses for Undergraduates and 52
for Graduates--Credit of Eight
Points Can Be Obtained.

At an enthusiastic meeting of
the football men last Monday in
the Trophy Room, plans were
gone over for the coming season,
and a schedule of work was outlined for the men during the summer months. Speeches were made
by Head Coach "Hank" Brennick,
Assistant Coach Paul Wilkinson,
Captain Brooks and Manager
Davis.
Coach Brennick announced that
practice would begin this year on
September 14th, as with the first
game scheduled for October 9th,
an early start was imperative. He
also laid stress on training during
vacation time, and asked especially that men intending to attend
military camps would do so early
in the summer. Due to the strenuous work in the camps, he said,
he was of the opinion that the men
would not be particularly inclined
to hard practice immediately after
military maneuvers. He also emphasized the fact that hard and serious practice were requisites for
a successful team, and asked that
the men help him turn out one of
the best teams that ever represented the Black and Blue.
Wilkinson, former captain and
all-state tackle, who will have
charge of the linemen this year,
also laid stress on the necessity
for hard work and earnest co-operation with the coaches. Captain
Brooks then spoke on the prospects and asked all to help in turning out another championship
eleven. Manager Davis outlined
the schedule for next season, and
the meeting disbanded with rousing cheers for coaches and captain.
Among the men present at the
meeting, several of whom are vet.erans, were: Finney, Ormond,
Primrose, Schmidt, Frank, Sonneborn, Woodward, Uhler, Martindale, Bowers, Brooks, Cox, Hoffman, Darley, Brumbaugh, Stanley
and Benson.

Ten departments of the University are represented in the list
of courses that may be offered by
advanced Ftudents at the Johns
Hopkins Summer School. The
program of twenty-four courses
includes the departments of chemistry, economics, education, English, German, history, mathematics, physics, politics and
psychology. In a number of instances the instruction to be given
will be along lines that are in addition to the work available during the regular session, such as
the money market and the European war, experimental education,
secc.ndary school teaching, • two
epochs of reform in German lahgnage and style, Pan-American
relations, radioactivity, international law and the European war,
and the experimental study of the
affective processes.
Undergraduate students in the
Academic Department will find an
array of thirty courses from which
their selections may be made.
These are in the departments of
biology, chemistry, economics,
education, English composition
and literature, French, geography,
German, history, Latin, mathematics, physics, politics, psychology and Spanish.
The former two-course rule regulating the choice of summer
courses has been modified. Students may elect two or three
courses for credit, at their own
option. The amount of credit that
may be earned is specified in accordance with the number so
elected. The maximum number,
of points that can be earned in
one session is eight points.
Undergraduate students in the
Department of Engineering can
offer for credit cow ses in chemistry, English composition and literature, French, German, mathematics and physics. A , new arrangement in the history of Englishb literature will make it possible to accomplish a full year's
course in two summer sessions.
